_exec_summary.SummaryText:
REGULATIONS AND PROGRAM LEVEL

This document contains the 2002 update of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Shell Oil Products U.S. Los Angeles Refinery (LAR) (formerly known as the Los Angeles Refining Company (LARC), a division of Equilon Enterprises LLC).  This update is designed to reflect changes to equipment and process in the LAR since the last RMP submission and include changes scheduled for implementation up through January/February 2003.  These changes are being implemented to comply with the new California Reformulated Fuels Gasoline regulations.  This RMP document complies with the requirements of the following regulations:

                U.S. EPA in 40CFR 68 for Risk Management Programs.

The refinery is required to meet the requirements Program Level 3 for this regulation because the covered processes in the refinery

a) do not meet the eligibility requirements for Program Level 1 as defined,
b) have a NAICS which is listed for Program Level 3, and 
c) are subject to the OSHA PSM standard in 29CFR1910.119.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Shell Oil Products U.S., Los Angeles Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker, public, and environmental safety.  Resources invested in accident prevention, such as the training of personnel and the consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes, demonstrate this commitment.  The LAR mission statement is ¿to lead the industry in safety, environmental and financial performance through the development and participation of all employees¿.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.  However, should a release occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release to the greatest extent possible.

The LAR process units and physical systems including the tank farm are divided into four areas referred to ¿asset areas¿.  The overall responsibility

of the day-to-day operation of each asset area is assigned to an individual, known as the ¿Asset Area Manager¿.  In addition to the asset areas, there are five technical departments at LAR.  The overall RMP Program responsibility resides with the LAR Refinery Manager.  The specific responsibility for the development and implementation of each RMP element is with the various asset area and technical department managers. The refinery has also designated the PSM/RMP Coordinator as the qualified person, who is responsible for coordinating the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program activities.

DESCRIPTION OF THE REFINERY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Los Angeles Refinery is located in an area that is zoned for heavy industrial use.  The 299-acre refinery is divided by Pacific Coast Highway with most of the facility located to the north of the highway.  Sepulveda Boulevard and the GATX Petroleum Company bound the northern portion of the refinery with Alameda Street and the Southern Pacific railroad tracks to the west and the Dominguez Channel to the east.  The area south of Pacific Coast Highway is a triangle-shaped parcel that approaches Anaheim Boulevard to the south and is bounded by Dominguez Channel to the east, and by the Shell LPG Marketing Sales Terminal to the west.

The refinery processes approximately 100,000 barrels of crude oil per day, through a variety of operations, including hydrocracking, hydrotreating, fluid catalytic cracking, delayed coking, and alkylation.  The products of the refinery include various petroleum products, such as liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), gasoline, jet fuel, and diesel fuel.   

For the purposes of the RMP, we have divided the refinery into four geographical areas based on the proximity of the covered processes to the various public receptors.  These areas and their covered processes are presented in Table 1. 

Based on threshold quantities listed for regulated toxic substances in the RMP Rule, LAR handles two r

endpoints are listed above.)  

A review of the covered processes was conducted and scenarios were identified that would be suitable for the worst-case release analysis.  Included was an examination of all the vessels and storage tanks within the processes to determine those with largest quantities of regulated substances.  Calculations were made of the inventories in all of the largest vessels in the covered processes with the vessels with the largest inventories of regulated toxic and flammable materials being selected.  

In selecting hypothetical worst-case release scenarios, additional consideration was given to high-pressure and high-temperature process vessels and those located near the refinery fence lines.  This approach takes into consideration smaller inventories that may result in greater distances from the refinery fence line for the specified toxic endpoint.  Also, consideration was given to those vessels that contain relatively high concentrations of hydrogen sulfide mixed with hydrocarbons. 

Once these vessels were identified, the EPA¿s RMP*CompTM was used to determine the distance to the endpoints for the worst-case release scenarios.  Vulnerability zones were drawn from the endpoint distances calculated.  A vulnerability zone is defined as a circle whose center is the point of release and its radius is the length of the endpoint plume, which is predicted by the dispersion model (e.g., RMP*CompTM).  Cases were selected that resulted in the largest vulnerability zones from the refinery areas into the vicinities of the public sectors around the refinery.  

Several possible consequences from the release of flammable substances were considered, including flash fire, pool fire, BLEVE, and vapor cloud explosion.  All these possibilities were analyzed, and it was concluded that a vapor cloud explosion was the most appropriate consequence for the worst-case analysis of the flammable releases.  

Four hypothetical worst-case release scenarios have been sel

egulated toxic substances, which are hydrogen sulfide and anhydrous ammonia.  Additionally, several regulated flammable substances are present, such as hydrogen, propylene, pentane, and butane.

Table 1:  Los Angeles Refinery Areas and Covered Processes

Refinery Area                     Covered Processes                      Not Covered Processes

East Area                             DCU, Crude Unit                                  GCP,  Tank Farm

West Area                  HCU, HTU-4, Ammonia Storage,                     HTU-1, HGU-2
                                   BENSAT, HTU-2 & 3, CRU-2 & 3,
                                   C4 Isom (Butamer), LPG and 
                                      Alkylation Storage Tanks

South Area                 FCCU and Alkylation Unit                        COGEN, SP&W, HCOD, LCOD, 
                                                                                                    Intermediate Product Storage

North Area                    Pentane Sphere                                  Crude, Intermediate Product, and 
                                                                                                    Final Product Storage Tanks
 
For the regulated toxic substances (anhydrous ammonia, hydrogen sulfide, and sulfuric acid/hydrocarbon emulsion) the toxic endpoints are as follows:
- Anhydrous Ammonia -- 200 ppm (0.14 mg/l
- Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S) -- 30 ppm (0.042 mg/l)

For the regulated flammable substances, the endpoints are as follows:
- Overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) for vapor cloud explosions
- Radiant heat of 5 kilowatts per square meter (kW/m2) for jet fires
- Lower flammability limit (LFL) for flash fires

WORST¿CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS

A worst-case release scenario has been defined in the EPA rule (§68.3) as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint defined in §68.22(a). (These

ected for the refinery: two for toxic chemical substances (anhydrous ammonia and hydrogen sulfide) and two for flammable substances (butylene, pentanes).  In this update, the toxic worst case scenarios have not changed from the previous RMP submission.  The worst-case scenario for flammable substances has been changed due to the construction of a new pentane sphere whose vulnerability zone exceeds the boundaries of the prior flammability scenario. Although completely within the bounds of the new flammable worst-case scenario's vulnerability zone, the previous flammable worst case scenario is being retained due to its breadth of exposure.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE ANALYSIS

Alternative scenarios are potential release cases that may result in vulnerability zones that extend beyond the refinery boundary.  The process of alternative release scenario identification was initiated with the review of the worst-case release cases.  Other vessels containing various quantities of regulated substances were then reviewed.  These were considered to have a higher likelihood of release.  In this process, all covered processes were reviewed and candidate cases for the alternative release scenario analysis were subsequently selected.  

Once the list of candidate scenarios was developed, computer dispersion analysis programs were used to model the selected scenarios.  (RMP*Comp was the primary model used; PHAST 5.2 was also used in 1999 to assess more complicated release scenarios such as combined hydrocarbon and toxic substance release.)  A review of the vulnerability zones resulting from the analysis of the alternative release scenarios then conducted.  In the alternative release scenario analysis, site-specific meteorological data were used.  The size of release was estimated from a hole-size that would result from equipment or pipe failure. The size of the holes were based on several factors, including pipe diameter, valve size, and pump seal size.  

The release duration was primaril

y based on the length of time that was necessary for the administering controls (including the operator) to stop the release.  In general, 20 minutes was a reasonable response time to stop most releases at the refinery.  In some cases, the duration of the release was shorter, which was dictated by the inventory of the material in the vessel(s) connected to the equipment.  The concept was to include at least one scenario for each toxic (ammonia and hydrogen sulfide) and one for the flammable materials for the refinery as a single stationary source.  On the other hand, because the size of the refinery makes it adjacent to several communities, the refinery wanted to include scenarios that could potentially impact those communities.  As a result, we selected four alternative release scenarios for toxic substances and six cases for flammable.  

In this update, none of the toxic or the flammable alternate release scenarios has changed from the previous RMP submission.  Additional alternate release scenarios are being added due to modifications at the refinery where vulnerability zones extend into regions previously unaffected by the previous alternate release scenarios.  

ACCIDENT HISTORY

The LAR plant has experienced three incidents during the last five years that meet the RMP requirements for the five-year accident history:

- Delayed Coking Unit (DCU) Fire in 2000.  This incident resulted in one serious contractor injury and minor equipment damage.  There were no offsite damages or injuries reported.

- Catalytic Reforming Unit 3 (CRU-3) Fire in 2000.  This incident resulted in two contractor injuries and minor equipment damage.  There were no offsite damages or injuries reported.

- General Plant H2S Odor Complaint from Neighboring Facility in 2000.  This incident resulted in no injuries or equipment damage.  There was an offsite odor complaint of H2S odors from an adjacent facility, although no damages or injuries were reported.  
 
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREV

ENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Los Angeles Refinery. 

Employee Participation
The LAR has instituted an employee participation program to consult with the employees in the development and implementation of all the Process Safety Management (PSM) elements and employee participation is encouraged at all levels of the organization.  Special groups, committees and individuals have been identified as having PSM responsibilities at the refinery. Nevertheless, all employees are encouraged to raise specific suggestions or concerns related to process safety management by contacting their immediate supervisor or the PSM coordinator.  The LAR Employee Participation Program is described in Standing Instruction PSM-1.

Process Safety Information
At the LAR, we have compiled process safety information for all processes containing hazardous or regulated materials as required by state and federal regulations, such as PSM, RMP, and CalARP.  This information has to do with process chemicals, technology, and equipment used in the handling, storage, and processing of regulated hazardous substances. Additionally, this compiled process safety information is used in the LAR PSM program as a resource for the teams performing process hazard analyses.  The information can also be helpful for the trainers who develop the training programs and the operating procedures, for the contractors whose employees will be working with the refinery processes, and for emergency responders in preparing for response should a release occur.  Standing Instruction PSM-2 that describes the Management of Change procedure also contains a roadmap to assist the user in finding the process safety information.

Process Hazard Analysis
A primary element of the LAR Prevention Program is the Process Hazard Analysis, or PHA.  The PHA is performed to identify hazards in a process. Through this process, information is obtained that will help impro

ve process safety and system reliability, as well as reducing the potential consequences of accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Because of the size and complexity of many of the refinery processes, the HAZOP methodology has been selected as the most appropriate PHA method in conducting the PHA for each process.  A HAZOP team at LAR typically consists of a process engineer, an experienced operator, an instrument & electrical engineer/technician, a mechanical engineer, and other part-time team members.  The team leader (a.k.a. the HAZOP facilitator) is fully knowledgeable in the proper implementation of the HAZOP methodology.  Part-time team members typically provide specialized expertise in areas such as safety and health, and equipment inspection/metallurgy/corrosion.  Standing Instruction PSM-3 summarizes the LAR procedure for conducting PHAs.

Operating Procedures
The LAR provides written operating procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as: process startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  The operating procedures describe tasks to be performed, data to be recorded, operating conditions to be maintained, samples to be collected, and safety and health precautions to be taken.  The LAR takes steps to update the procedures to reflect current operations and the procedures are certified annually by the operating staff.  In addition, operating procedures are updated when there are any changes in the process as a result of the management of change procedures.  

Training
Another primary element of the LAR Prevention Program is Training.  The training program consists of both job skill (qualification) and safety training.  The qualification training programs are described in the Standing Instructions of O-43 (Operation Training Policy) and M-41 (Maintenance Training Policy), which clearly establish the goals and objectives that the refinery wishes to ach

ieve with the employees.  The LAR provides initial training to new hires and regular refresher training to the refinery employees.  The job skill training is presented in various forms and degrees and is dependent on the skills required for the employee's job or position.  The purpose of this training is to elevate the aptitude and knowledge of the operation and maintenance personnel of the process control and technology used and the equipment operated in the refinery.  All employees, including maintenance and contractor employees, involved with highly hazardous chemicals and regulated substances are provided with safety training.  The goal of the safety training is to provide information to the workers so they will understand the recognized hazards of the processes and chemicals that they work with and around.   

Contractors
The Los Angeles Refinery has established the Contractor Safety Program (Standing Instruction SAF-30) as a screening process that helps identify and select contractors who will perform work in and around processes that involve hazardous chemicals.  Such contractors must have the appropriate skills, knowledge, and certifications for the job tasks which they are being employed.  For contractors whose safety performance on the job is not known, the LAR obtains information on injury and illness rates and references regarding the contractor.  An evaluation is also conducted of contractor work methods and experiences.  Thus, contractors without safety programs or with unacceptable safety records will not be invited to perform works at the LAR.

Management of Change
The LAR has implemented a Management of Change (MOC) procedure (Standing Instruction PSM-2) to manage changes to the refinery units.  Changes are defined as modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials, or processing conditions other than replacement in kind¿.  
PSM-2 includes modifications in the operating procedures that contain operating parameters such as pressure limits, tem

perature ranges, flow rates, and other process variables.  The Management of Change procedure also covers changes in process technology and changes to equipment and instrumentation.  Changes in process technology can result from changes in production rates, raw materials, experimentation, equipment unavailability, new equipment, new product development, change in catalyst and changes in operating conditions to improve yield or quality.  Equipment changes include, among others, change in materials of construction, equipment specifications, capacity, piping pre-arrangements, experimental equipment, computer program revisions, and changes in alarms and interlocks.  
Temporary changes are also subject to the management of change provisions in PSM-2 and the procedure also insures that the equipment and operating procedures are returned to their original or designed conditions at the end of the temporary change.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
A pre-startup safety review (PSSR) is carried out in conjunction with an MOC or a new project or construction.  The PSSR is conducted before implementing a modification to a process, or commissioning a new project.  
As it is LAR practice to conduct a PHA for various types of changes and for all new projects, there could be some recommendations resulting from the PHA that are required to be addressed before implementation.  A PSSR is carried out in the form of a checklist to comply with requirements of the applicable regulations.

Mechanical Integrity
A mechanical integrity program is in place for the continued integrity of process equipment at LAR.  Equipment used to process, transfer or store hazardous chemicals have been designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.  This program covers: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief systems and safety devices, emergency shutdown systems, electronic controls, and rotating equipment (e.g., pumps and compressors.)  L

AR also reviews the maintenance programs and shutdown schedules to determine if there are areas where breakdown maintenance is used rather than an on-going mechanical integrity program.  Elements of the mechanical integrity program are as follows: (1) categorization of equipment and instrumentation, (2) inspection and testing program, (3) maintenance program, (4) documentation, and (5) quality assurance program.

Hot Work Permit
All non-routine work, and some routine work, conducted in process areas at the refinery are controlled using specific company instructions, described in the Standing Instructions SAF-4 (Hot Work Permits), SAF-3 (Safe Work Permits), and SAF-5 (Entry Work Permit). Although the three permit programs are mutually dependent, the regulations only specify the Hot Work Permit which is discussed below.
A hot work permit describes the steps that operating, maintenance and contractor personnel must follow to obtain the necessary clearance to perform different types of work involving hot surfaces, flame, or energized equipment.  The hazards identified for the work being performed are communicated to those personnel performing the work and also to those personnel who may be affected by the work being performed, especially when the work being performed could affect the safety of the process.  The hot work permit procedures refer to and coordinate the following procedures and authorizations, as applicable: lockout/tagout, line breaking, and confined space entry.

Incident Investigation
Standing Instruction SAF-11 outlines the LAR incident investigation procedure.  It applies to the investigation of different types of incidents that may occur in the facility.  The intent of an incident investigation is to identify the cause of incidents and to prevent or minimize their recurrence.  A multi-disciplinary team is assembled to gather the facts of the events and to identify, to the extent possible, the cause of the incident.  Team members are selected on the b

asis of their training, knowledge, and ability to contribute to a team effort to investigate the incident and usually include an operator from the area where the incident occurred.  The operator¿s knowledge of the events can help to identify and verify relevant facts about the incident.  It is the goal of the investigation to treat all involved individuals in a fair, open and consistent manner.  The incident report, its findings and recommendations are entered in the incident investigation tracking system, which can be accessed by all employees, and also distributed to others who can benefit from the information.

Compliance Audits
In compliance with Shell's corporate policies, the refinery has implemented an Environmental, Health, and Safety Compliance Assurance Program.  The program helps to verify that LAR's programs and practices comply with applicable laws and regulations. Every three years, the refinery undergoes an Environmental Audit, a Health and Safety Compliance Audit, and PSM/RMP Compliance Audits  conducted by Shell Corporate staff.  The audit approach includes the following steps: (1) pre-audit preparation, (2) on-site field review, and (3) post-audit follow-up.  The audit team is composed of qualified staff from whom a leader will be assigned to be responsible for these steps.

CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The accident prevention programs summarized previously apply to all the covered processes and their related hazards.  These programs help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures or human errors.  In addition to the accident prevention program activities, LAR has safety features on many units to help contain or control potential releases, quickly detect a release, and reduce (mitigate) the potential consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes.

- Release Detection
     - Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
     - Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) detectors with ala

rms

- Release Containment and Control
     - Pressure relief valves that discharge to the refinery flare system to capture and incinerate sporadic releases from pressure excursions
     - Scrubber to neutralize sulfuric acid fume
     - Emergency valves to isolate the release source from the release points (manual and automated)
     - Automated emergency shutdown switches for process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)
     - Dike areas around storage tanks to contain liquid releases
     - Redundant equipment and instrumentation (uninterrupted power supply for process control system, backup firewater pumps, etc.)
     - Atmospheric relief devices, where necessary

- Release Mitigation
     - Fire suppression and extinguishing systems 
     - Deluge system for LPG storage tanks and ammonia tank
     - Trained emergency response personnel
     - Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
     - Blast-resistant control room to help protect control systems and personnel

As part of the process safety program, the LAR has made an effort to reduce the number and quantities of regulated substances stored on site.  For example, the refinery phased out chlorine used for cooling water treatment and replaced it with bleach.  Also, a hydrogen production process has been shut down thereby eliminating the presence of a dilute gas (a mixture of hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide) in an underground line.  This project also resulted in the reduction of anhydrous ammonia consumption by over 30%.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Los Angeles Refinery has implemented an emergency response program (ERP) to prepare for potential incidents, respond to them effectively, and recover from their impacts.  The ERP has included a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxic gases (ammonia and hydrogen sulfide), accidental release of flammable materials resulting

ergency could result or has resulted in offsite consequences. 

LAR maintains an industrial fire brigade, which consists of three emergency response (ER) teams, specialized in rescue, hazardous materials, and spill containment.  Each ER team is lead by a captain and consists of six to nine members.  External sources provide assistance in the form of alerting the public, evacuation, transportation, and providing hazard mitigation equipment, supplies, and personnel to complement LAR capabilities. It should be emphasized that external assistance is requested only during a Level 3 emergency.  In addition to these sources, LAR has coordinated with the local hospitals, clinics, and doctors about the properties of the various types of hazardous materials processed and handled at the refinery.  All ER team members, ER team captains, and asset safety coordinators are required to attend quarterly onsite training.  Outside training is also provided annually to various ERT members, shift supervisors, and asset safety coordinators.  Emergency training and ICS role-play is provided annually to the emergency response management organization.

COMMUNICATION WITH THE PUBLIC

Pursuant to the requirements of the RMP Rule, Shell Oil Products US Los Angeles Refinery, in a joint effort with other local RMP-covered industry companies in Southern California, has made strides to establish a sound communication link with the communities surrounding the industrial facilities.  The primary objectives of this endeavor have been to: (a) share with the public our knowledge about the operations and activities, as well as the hazards of our facilities, (b) learn from the public their interests and concerns, and (c) establish an on-going relationship with the community regarding potential risks of the facilities.  

Since the initial presentations and discussions regarding the RMP rule, the LAR has maintained an open line of communication with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) for the re

in a fire and explosion, and accidental spill of hazardous materials on the ground within the refinery perimeter.  

LAR uses an Emergency Management Organization, known as Incident Command System (ICS), to respond and manage incidents.  The ICS has a hierarchical (chain of command) structure, which places the highest responsibility on the Emergency Manager, who has the overall responsibility for the emergency.  The Emergency Manager delegates direct command responsibilities to the Incident Commander, who has the highest authority during an emergency.  The Emergency Manger is a liaison between the Incident Commander, the public, and the Company.  The next level of responsibility resides on four section chiefs: Command Chief, Operations Chief, Planning Chief, and Logistics/Finance Chief.  All section chiefs receive directions from the Incident Commander during an emergency.  Each position in the organization has specific assignments and responsibilities, which are defined in the ERP.  The ICS is expanded or contracted to meet the needs or requirements of an emergency.  As the scope and complexity of an emergency expands so does the Incident Command System.

The refinery has a three-tier emergency activation system in place.  A Level 1 emergency is defined as an event, which can occur at a local work area (e.g., a unit), with minor consequences to health or property, which would not have an impact on the other units in the refinery.  A Level 1 emergency is handled by the personnel available on the unit and does not require assistance from personnel outside of the work area.  A Level 2 emergency is a refinery emergency that would not require assistance from responders outside of LAR, but would require additional resources from the LAR Fire Brigade.  The highest level of an emergency is Level 3, which is defined as an emergency of a size and scope that would require outside resources.  A Level 3 emergency is triggered when life and property are endangered or when the em

finery.  The LEPC is kept informed of significant changes to the refinery operations relevant to their jurisdiction.  If after being informed of a proposed or implemented change, the LEPC suggests that further public discussions were warranted, LAR management would take the appropriate steps to provide the required information for communication about the changes to the RMP information to community groups.


DESCRIPTION OF PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
- The Alliance Refining Council, which is made of the Alliance ten refinery managers have initiated ten Process Safety Improvement teams to review the majority of the PSM element and develop best practice that will enhance PSM to exceed regulatory requirements. The Alliance goal is to lead the industry in PSM.
- The Shell Oil Products US, Los Angeles Refinery has developed a five year plan to perform: 
     - Corrosion control documents and pressurized equipment inspection studies
     - Alarm objective analysis studies, 
     - PRV and flare system capacity studies
     - Reliability-centered maintenance program
     - Protective instrumentation system studies
     - Ensure Safe Operations studies
     - Goal and Measurement programs
for each process unit. These documents will enhance the quality of the PSI and will be used during the PHA discussions.
- Review and revise incident investigation process with the intention of expanding it to a three-level program.

Since the last RMP submission, the LAR has achieved the following:
- Increased the number of hydrocarbon monitors at the Alky unit to detect any light hydrocarbon leaks. The plant management approved preliminary engineering and acquiring cost estimate for this project.
- Instituted the new management philosophy toward PSM is to increase field employee participation to PSM and become a culture in employee day to day activities.  
- LAR was awarded the Shell CEO Safety Award for safe operation, as well as received several safety awards from local community o
